image.altText: A woman in blue jumper and white scarf crouches down with her black dog with white facial hairs.

items.synopsis: The beauty and wonder of the natural world is what keeps scientists like Dana Bergstrom fighting to protect it. She's one of many who say speaking out comes at a cost  but not speaking up can take an even greater personal toll.

title.children: 'The public needs to know': Ecologists and climate scientists reveal devastating culture of suppression

image.altText: A fire truck in front of flames at night

items.synopsis: Two dangerous bushfires are burning in southern Queensland with residents in Tara, Kogan and Wieambilla told to evacuate. At least five structures, including an unknown number of homes, have been lost.

title.children: Homes lost as 'severe' bushfires spread west of Toowoomba

image.altText: Roof tops of houses

items.synopsis: The top 10 locations attracting dozens of enquiries on a single property across the state have been revealed.

title.children: More than 100 people are enquiring for a single rental property in this Queensland location

image.altText: Anthony Albanese stands next to a screen that says "helping Australia seize the AI era".

items.synopsis: Tech giant Microsoft will help Australia build a "cyber shield" as part of a plan to sink billions of dollars into securing and expanding the national digital economy, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese reveals on a trip to the US.

title.children: Albanese, Microsoft reveal tech giant's biggest-ever investment in Australia

image.altText: A person uses a ruler to measure someone's feet.

items.synopsis: An investigation into the business practices of a podiatrist who describes himself as probably the highest-paid practitioner in Australia has exposed some deep failings in the health system that open it up to rorting and privacy breaches.

title.children: 'Unpoliced pots of gold': The questionable business practices in podiatry

image.altText: A satellite image of a tropical cyclone

items.synopsis: Seven months after being battered by twin cyclones, Vanuatu is bracing for another one as cyclone Lola bears down on the country's second-biggest city.

title.children: Just months after 'evil twin' cyclones, Vanuatu braces for new 'destructive' category 5 cyclone Lola

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair sitting at the beach on a log overlooking the water.

items.synopsis: Lee-Ann Lovegrove's cancer story started when she was just 11. Now 47, the central Queensland woman says she is living proof that a positive mind and body can help combat disease.

title.children: How a cancer journey that started when Lee-Ann was a child helped her live a happy, healthy life

image.altText: Women stand with two armed militants

items.synopsis: The two freed hostages who were released by Hamas have landed in Tel Aviv, Israel, with footage showing soldiers carrying the women on stretchers from a helicopter into Ichilov hospital. Follow live.

title.children: Freed hostages arrive at Israel medical facility, UN calls for return of remaining hostages and urgent ceasefire

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Five of Gaza's main hospitals have erected tents to accommodate patients, according to the UN's Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs. Among them, says the UN's latest report, is Shifa Hospital in Gaza City, which is "treating some 5,000 patients, significantly over its capacity of 700 patients". "[This is] in addition to approximately 45,000 [displaced people] taking refuge within and around the hospital," the report said. "These and other hospitals are on the brink of collapse due to the shortage of electricity, medicine, equipment and specialised personnel. "Large numbers of patients are being treated on the ground given there are not enough hospital beds."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Gaza hospital built to treat 700 now treating 5,000, says UN

children.content: Five of Gaza's main hospitals have erected tents to accommodate patients, according to the UN's Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs.
Among them, says the UN's latest report, is Shifa Hospital in Gaza City, which is "treating some 5,000 patients, significantly over its capacity of 700 patients".
"[This is] in addition to approximately 45,000 [displaced people] taking refuge within and around the hospital," the report said.
"These and other hospitals are on the brink of collapse due to the shortage of electricity, medicine, equipment and specialised personnel.
"Large numbers of patients are being treated on the ground given there are not enough hospital beds."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As of October 23, 12 hospitals and 46 primary care clinics in Gaza "are no longer functioning", the UN's Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs says. The group's latest report says 34 health care facilities and 24 ambulances have been affected since October 7. "All hospitals are implementing emergency contingency plans that affect functioning and access to health care," the report said. It added the extent of damage "sustained by educational facilities and other civilian infrastructure" is a growing concern. "As of October 21, 206 educational facilities have been affected, including at least 29 [United Nations] schools," they said. "Eight of these schools were used as emergency shelters for [displaced people], with one of them being directly hit." There are now 590,000 people staying in 150 UN shelters, 101,500 sheltering in churches and hospitals, and almost 71,999 in 67 non-UN schools, according to the UN's estimate.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 12 hospitals 'no longer functioning' and hundreds of schools damaged

children.content: As of October 23, 12 hospitals and 46 primary care clinics in Gaza "are no longer functioning", the UN's Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs says.
The group's latest report says 34 health care facilities and 24 ambulances have been affected since October 7.
"All hospitals are implementing emergency contingency plans that affect functioning and access to health care," the report said.
It added the extent of damage "sustained by educational facilities and other civilian infrastructure" is a growing concern.
"As of October 21, 206 educational facilities have been affected, including at least 29 [United Nations] schools," they said.
"Eight of these schools were used as emergency shelters for [displaced people], with one of them being directly hit."
There are now 590,000 people staying in 150 UN shelters, 101,500 sheltering in churches and hospitals, and almost 71,999 in 67 non-UN schools, according to the UN's estimate.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israeli bombardments across the Gaza Strip have intensified "three-fold" compared to previous days, says the latest UN update. The UN's Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs says the deadliest attacks in the last 24 hours included "several airstrikes on residential buildings in Jabalia Refugee Camp" and in northern Gaza. "Furthermore, in the last 24 hours, two UNRWA installations, one in Al Bureij camp and the other in Nuseirat in the middle area, sustained collateral damage due to airstrikes in the surrounding areas of these facilities," the report said. The estimated death toll among Palestines has now surpassed 5,000 according to the Palestinian Ministry of Health.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel's air strikes in Gaza intensify 'three-fold', says UN

children.content: Israeli bombardments across the Gaza Strip have intensified "three-fold" compared to previous days, says the latest UN update.

The UN's Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs says the deadliest attacks in the last 24 hours included "several airstrikes on residential buildings in Jabalia Refugee Camp" and in northern Gaza.

"Furthermore, in the last 24 hours, two UNRWA installations, one in Al Bureij camp and the other in Nuseirat in the middle area, sustained collateral damage due to airstrikes in the surrounding areas of these facilities," the report said.
The estimated death toll among Palestines has now surpassed 5,000 according to the Palestinian Ministry of Health.

props.alt: A graph showing the number of israeli and palestinian casualties

children.content: (United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs)

image.altText: koala latching on to tree staring into camera

image.altText: A cartoon image of Jacinta Allan's face.

items.synopsis: Victorian Premier Jacinta Allan is among those criticising a nude depiction of her published in the Herald Sun, describing it as "sexualised imagery" — but the cartoonist has defended his work as "fair political comment".

image.altText: Bag of blood from transfusion.

image.altText: Very close up of a green cicada

title.children: What's behind the chirping crickets and singing cicadas that herald the summer months?

image.altText: Yellow and red images of a timeline of a solar eclipse which is when the moon covers most of the sun

items.synopsis: The other side of the world was treated to a 'ring of fire' annular solar eclipse. Here's a look at the celestial event in a way never seen before.

title.children: Australia missed out on the 'ring of fire' solar eclipse, but new imagery gives us a taste to what it was like

image.altText: A man tsands next to a grave with a white cross.

items.synopsis: Like many remote Indigenous communities, Yarrabah voted overwhelmingly in favour of a Voice to Parliament. The result of the referendum has left leaders feeling "rejected".

title.children: The people of Yarrabah feel 'rejected' by the Voice result and hoped a Yes vote would stop residents dying young

image.altText: A hand holds an electric vehicle charging plug against a car.

items.synopsis: Energy Minister Mick de Brenni tells those making the switch to electric: there will be an EV charger nearby.

image.altText: a plane flys over a city skyline

items.synopsis: Joseph David Emerson, 44, faces 83 counts each of attempted murder and reckless endangerment after the incident.

title.children: Off-duty pilot allegedly tries to shut down passenger jet's engines mid-flight, charged with attempted murder

subjects.title: Air and Space Accidents and Incidents

image.altText: Middle-aged woman and man sitting on a couch smiling at the camera, petting two dogs.

items.synopsis: From pet-sitting goats to seeing rainbows at Uluru and making friends in new outback towns, the grandparents are living a totally different life to the one they had — and they love it.

image.altText: An Israeli soldier dressed in uniform and wearing a helmet holds up his hand to a journalist.

items.synopsis: The town of Shlomi is one of dozens of communities within 2 kilometres of Israel's border with Lebanon that have been evacuated over fears that a second front line could open up in the north and drag in other regional players. Here's what the ABC found on a visit there.

image.altText: Typewriter generic

items.synopsis: A "surprising" writing trend has emerged, according to typewriter enthusiasts who say school students are better engaging with the more tactile creative process.

image.altText: The back of a white and blue police car beside a two-story house with a red door.

items.synopsis: The woman was found dead in her kitchen with stab wounds on Monday evening. Her 70-year-old male partner remains under police guard in hospital.

image.altText: A photo of a child in school uniform attached to a fridge.

items.synopsis: Marjorie identified as a woman, but was put in with men in Tasmania's Risdon Prison. Eventually, she refused treatment for an illness and died. Now, her family wants an investigation — saying authorities knew she was at risk of abuse.

title.children: 'They're killing me, mum': Marjorie was in a men's prison for years. Then she died

image.altText: A green energy drink can seen from above its pull tab

items.synopsis: Students preparing for exams across Australia are being advised to carefully manage their intake of caffeine, after a pre-exam crackdown by health authorities in one state found energy drinks being sold with almost twice the permissible amount.

title.children: Exam cram warning as one energy drink found to contain 300mg of caffeine per can

items.synopsis: Rajabu Mudanzi fled the Democratic Republic of Congo decades ago and eventually settled in Australia. Speaking 10 languages, the man who "likes to help" is now working as a police liaison officer in Townsville.

title.children: Coming from a country where 'police are killers', Rajabu's new job helping connect cultures may seem surprising

image.altText: Bobi the dog sitting on the grass.

items.synopsis: Officials at the Guinness World Records say they are "saddened to learn of the death of Bobi, the world's oldest dog ever."

image.altText: a lady wearing a baby blue top sitting in her lounge smiling at the camera.

items.synopsis: The government forecasts it can divert 27,000 people who would otherwise join the National Disability Insurance Scheme into different disability programs. Participants with psychosocial disability say they shouldn't be targeted as a "lesser" group that is not given equal access to the NDIS.

title.children: As NDIS overhaul nears, participants fear for 'unknown 27,000' who may miss out
